docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Frieda S. Miller, Director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, today announced a project under the international exchange of persons program, through which five representatives of women's groups in Mexico and...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Frieda S. Miller, Director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, today announced a project under the international exchange of persons program, through which five representatives of women's groups in Mexico and South America will study seven women's organizations in this country.

headline.main: SENORAS WILL VISIT U. S. WOMEN'S GROUPS

docs.snippet: MEXICO CITY, April 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Union today joined the United States in refusing to sign the proposed international agreement dividing short wave radio frequencies.
docs.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, April 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Union today joined the United States in refusing to sign the proposed international agreement dividing short wave radio frequencies.

headline.main: RUSSIA, U. S. BAR PACT AS RADIO PARLEY ENDS

docs.snippet: Pound sterling was shaken sharply last week, the spot rate getting down to $4.02 3/4, while the discounts on forwards widened to more than 3 cents on 90's and about 8 cents on six-month contracts. In each instance these are new lows since February,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pound sterling was shaken sharply last week, the spot rate getting down to $4.02 3/4, while the discounts on forwards widened to more than 3 cents on 90's and about 8 cents on six-month contracts. In each instance these are new lows since February, 1948.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended April 8, 1949.

docs.snippet: ANTOFAGASTA, Chile, April 11 -- A major clash over the seating of the Peruvian and Venezuelan delegates is threatened at the fourth regional conference of the International Labor Organization, which will open in Montevideo, Uruguay, on the 25th.
docs.lead_paragraph: ANTOFAGASTA, Chile, April 11 -- A major clash over the seating of the Peruvian and Venezuelan delegates is threatened at the fourth regional conference of the International Labor Organization, which will open in Montevideo, Uruguay, on the 25th.

headline.main: ILO CLASH LIKELY IN LATIN AMERICA; Regional Parley Is Expected to Dispute Seating of Delegates From Peru, Venezuela

byline.original: By MILTON BRACKERSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: ANNECY, France, April 11 -- President Truman will soon send the charter of the International Trade Organization to Congress for approval, the United States advised the delegates of thirty-five countries at the opening here today of the largest tariff...
docs.lead_paragraph: ANNECY, France, April 11 -- President Truman will soon send the charter of the International Trade Organization to Congress for approval, the United States advised the delegates of thirty-five countries at the opening here today of the largest tariff conference ever held.
docs.abstract: A Philip (France) stresses need for more, s, Annecy

headline.main: CONGRESS TO WEIGH WORLD TRADE PLAN; U. S. Advises Delegates at ITO Parley That Truman Will Submit Charter Soon MEETING OPENS AT ANNECY Full Support of Washington Is Pledged to Negotiators in Message From Acheson

byline.original: By MICHAEL L. HOFFMANSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights elected eight new members and re-elected four old ones today to its subcommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press.
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, April 11 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights elected eight new members and re-elected four old ones today to its subcommission on Freedom of Information and of the Press.
docs.abstract: 8 new members elected; 4 re-elected; Prof Chafee (US), A R K McKenzie (GB) and J A Lomakin (USSR) replaced

headline.main: EIGHT NEW FIGURES ON U. N. PRESS UNIT; Commission on Human Rights Also Re-elects 4 to Body on Freedom of Information

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: A debate on whether the Hungarian trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and the Bulgarian prosecution of fifteen Protestant leaders violated the human rights and fundamental freedoms clauses of the United Nations Charter and peace treaties was...
docs.lead_paragraph: A debate on whether the Hungarian trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and the Bulgarian prosecution of fifteen Protestant leaders violated the human rights and fundamental freedoms clauses of the United Nations Charter and peace treaties was authorized by the General Assembly yesterday by a 30-to-7 vote, with twenty naitons abstaining.
docs.abstract: UN Assembly votes 30-7 to debate trial; 20 nations abstain; USSR bloc opposes plan

headline.main: U. N. WILL DEBATE RELIGIOUS TRIALS; THE VOTE IS 30 TO 7; Soviet Bloc Fights the Plan as Violating Internal Rights of Hungary and Bulgaria
